abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Objective</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Previous studies have proposed that food intakes are associated with the risk of urolithiasis. Here, we conducted a two-sample Mendelian randomization (MR) study to evaluate the causal effects of different food intakes on urolithiasis.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Independent genetic variants associated with different food intakes at a genome-wide significant level were selected from summary-level statistics of genome-wide association studies from the UK Biobank. The association of these instrumental variables with urolithiasis was studied in a cohort from FinnGen Consortium.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Among the 15 studied food intake exposures, tea intake (odds ratio [OR] = 0.433, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 0.281–0.667, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> value = 1.470 × 10<jats:sup>–4</jats:sup>) and fresh fruit intake (OR = 0.358, 95% CI = 0.185–0.694, <jats:italic>p</jats:italic> value = 0.002) were found to significantly reduce the risk of the calculus of kidney and ureter. The association remained consistent in the sensitivity analyses. After adjusting for the effects of vitamin D and vitamin C, fresh fruit intake remained the reverse causal association with the calculus of kidney and ureter.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>Genetically proxied fresh fruit intake is causally associated with a reduced risk of the calculus of kidney and ureter.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec>

title: Mendelian randomization analysis reveals fresh fruit intake as a protective factor for urolithiasis
